content.text: The following is metadata about Dandiset 001433 version 0.250507.2356.
The following is a listing of some of the files in the Dandiset.
The following is metadata and usage information about the file sub-4122/sub-4122_ses-20250507T152927_ecephys.nwb.

import pynwb
import h5py
import remfile

# Load
from dandi.dandiapi import DandiAPIClient

client = DandiAPIClient()
dandiset = client.get_dandiset("001433", "0.250507.2356")
url = next(dandiset.get_assets_by_glob("sub-4122/sub-4122_ses-20250507T152927_ecephys.nwb")).download_url

remote_file = remfile.File(url)
h5_file = h5py.File(remote_file)
io = pynwb.NWBHDF5IO(file=h5_file)
nwb = io.read()

nwb # (NWBFile)
nwb.session_description # (str) LFP and sniff recording
nwb.identifier # (str) 4122_4
nwb.session_start_time # (datetime) 2025-05-07T15:29:27.359523-07:00
nwb.timestamps_reference_time # (datetime) 2025-05-07T15:29:27.359523-07:00
nwb.file_create_date # (list) [datetime.datetime(2025, 5, 7, 15, 29, 27, 359523, tzinfo=tzoffset(None, -25200))]
nwb.experimenter # (tuple) ['Rafilson, Sidney']
nwb.acquisition # (LabelledDict)
acquisition = nwb.acquisition
LFP = acquisition["LFP"]
LFP # (ElectricalSeries)
LFP.starting_time # (float64) 0.0
LFP.rate # (float64) 1000.0
LFP.resolution # (float64) -1.0
LFP.comments # (str) no comments
LFP.description # (str) LFP signal from olfactory bulb
LFP.conversion # (float64) 1.0
LFP.offset # (float64) 0.0
LFP.unit # (str) volts
LFP.data # (Dataset) shape (1969184, 16); dtype float64
# LFP.data[:, :] # Access all data
# LFP.data[0:n, :] # Access first n rows
# LFP.data[:, 0:n] # Access first n columns
LFP.starting_time_unit # (str) seconds
LFP.electrodes # (DynamicTableRegion)
LFP.electrodes.description # (str) All LFP electrodes
LFP.electrodes.table # (DynamicTable)
LFP.electrodes.table.description # (str) metadata about extracellular electrodes
LFP.electrodes.table.colnames # (tuple) ['location', 'group', 'group_name', 'filtering']
LFP.electrodes.table.columns # (tuple)
LFP.electrodes.table.id # (ElementIdentifiers)
# LFP.electrodes.table.to_dataframe() # (DataFrame) Convert to a pandas DataFrame with 16 rows and 4 columns
# LFP.electrodes.table.to_dataframe().head() # (DataFrame) Show the first few rows of the pandas DataFrame
LFP.electrodes.table.location # (VectorData) the location of channel within the subject e.g. brain region
LFP.electrodes.table.group # (VectorData) a reference to the ElectrodeGroup this electrode is a part of
LFP.electrodes.table.group_name # (VectorData) the name of the ElectrodeGroup this electrode is a part of
LFP.electrodes.table.filtering # (VectorData) description of hardware filtering, including the filter name and frequency cutoffs
SniffSignal = acquisition["SniffSignal"]
SniffSignal # (TimeSeries)
SniffSignal.starting_time # (float64) 0.0
SniffSignal.rate # (float64) 1000.0
SniffSignal.resolution # (float64) -1.0
SniffSignal.comments # (str) no comments
SniffSignal.description # (str) Raw sniff thermistor voltage
SniffSignal.conversion # (float64) 1.0
SniffSignal.offset # (float64) 0.0
SniffSignal.unit # (str) volts
SniffSignal.data # (Dataset) shape (1969184,); dtype float64
# SniffSignal.data[:] # Access all data
# SniffSignal.data[0:n] # Access first n elements
SniffSignal.starting_time_unit # (str) seconds
nwb.keywords # (StrDataset) shape (5,); dtype object
# nwb.keywords[:] # Access all data
# nwb.keywords[0:n] # Access first n elements
# First few values of nwb.keywords: ['olfactory bulb' 'LFP' 'sniffing' 'mouse' 'neuroscience']
nwb.processing # (LabelledDict)
processing = nwb.processing
behavior = processing["behavior"]
behavior # (ProcessingModule)
behavior.description # (str) Sniff event features
behavior.data_interfaces # (LabelledDict)
data_interfaces = behavior.data_interfaces
exhalation_time = data_interfaces["exhalation_time"]
exhalation_time # (TimeSeries)
exhalation_time.resolution # (float64) -1.0
exhalation_time.comments # (str) no comments
exhalation_time.description # (str) exhalation_time (s)
exhalation_time.conversion # (float64) 1.0
exhalation_time.offset # (float64) 0.0
exhalation_time.unit # (str) NA
exhalation_time.data # (Dataset) shape (10030,); dtype int64
# exhalation_time.data[:] # Access all data
# exhalation_time.data[0:n] # Access first n elements
exhalation_time.timestamps # (Dataset) shape (10030,); dtype float64
# exhalation_time.timestamps[:] # Access all data
# exhalation_time.timestamps[0:n] # Access first n elements
exhalation_time.timestamps_unit # (str) seconds
exhalation_time.interval # (int) 1
inhalation_time = data_interfaces["inhalation_time"]
inhalation_time # (TimeSeries)
inhalation_time.resolution # (float64) -1.0
inhalation_time.comments # (str) no comments
inhalation_time.description # (str) inhalation_time (s)
inhalation_time.conversion # (float64) 1.0
inhalation_time.offset # (float64) 0.0
inhalation_time.unit # (str) NA
inhalation_time.data # (Dataset) shape (10030,); dtype int64
# inhalation_time.data[:] # Access all data
# inhalation_time.data[0:n] # Access first n elements
inhalation_time.timestamps # (Dataset) shape (10030,); dtype float64
# inhalation_time.timestamps[:] # Access all data
# inhalation_time.timestamps[0:n] # Access first n elements
inhalation_time.timestamps_unit # (str) seconds
inhalation_time.interval # (int) 1
nwb.electrode_groups # (LabelledDict)
electrode_groups = nwb.electrode_groups
LFPGroup = electrode_groups["LFPGroup"]
LFPGroup # (ElectrodeGroup)
LFPGroup.description # (str) LFP recording electrodes
LFPGroup.location # (str) Olfactory Bulb
LFPGroup.device # (Device)
LFPGroup.device.description # (str) OpenEphys recording system
nwb.devices # (LabelledDict)
devices = nwb.devices
OpenEphys = devices["OpenEphys"]
OpenEphys # (Device)
OpenEphys.description # (str) OpenEphys recording system
nwb.experiment_description # (str) LFP and sniff behavior recording
nwb.lab # (str) Smear lab
nwb.institution # (str) University of Oregon
nwb.electrodes # (DynamicTable)
nwb.electrodes.description # (str) metadata about extracellular electrodes
nwb.electrodes.colnames # (tuple) ['location', 'group', 'group_name', 'filtering']
nwb.electrodes.columns # (tuple)
nwb.electrodes.id # (ElementIdentifiers)
# nwb.electrodes.to_dataframe() # (DataFrame) Convert to a pandas DataFrame with 16 rows and 4 columns
# nwb.electrodes.to_dataframe().head() # (DataFrame) Show the first few rows of the pandas DataFrame
nwb.electrodes.location # (VectorData) the location of channel within the subject e.g. brain region
nwb.electrodes.group # (VectorData) a reference to the ElectrodeGroup this electrode is a part of
nwb.electrodes.group_name # (VectorData) the name of the ElectrodeGroup this electrode is a part of
nwb.electrodes.filtering # (VectorData) description of hardware filtering, including the filter name and frequency cutoffs
nwb.subject # (Subject)
nwb.subject.age # (str) P90D
nwb.subject.age__reference # (str) birth
nwb.subject.description # (str) Lab mouse used for sniffing + LFP experiment
nwb.subject.sex # (str) M
nwb.subject.species # (str) Mus musculus
nwb.subject.subject_id # (str) 4122

content:
On the basis of the above information, please create a jupytext notebook that introduces dandiset 001433 using the format described below.

The purpose of the notebook is to help researchers explore the dandiset and get started with a reanalysis.

Start with an appropriate title for the notebook, such as "Exploring Dandiset 001433: ..." (that should be a markdown heading).

Inform the user that the notebook was generated with the assistance of AI, and that they should be cautious when interpreting the code or results.

Provide an overview of the Dandiset. Include a link to the Dandiset of the form https://dandiarchive.org/dandiset/001433/0.250507.2356.

Summarize what the notebook covers.

List the packages that are required to run the notebook. Assume that these are already installed on the user's system. Do not include any pip install commands in the notebook.

Show how to use the DANDI API to load assets.

Show how to load and visualize data from the dandiset based on the above information. Feel free to organize things differently from how they are in the above information, but do not make up new information.

Generate good quality plots (without being redundant).

Load NWB data by streaming the remote file (as done in the above information) rather than downloading it.

Do not use any functionality of pynwb or dandi that is not covered in the above information.

You should stick to material that is covered in the above information and do not hallucinate.

Throughout the notebook, include explanatory markdown cells that guide the user through the process.

The notebook should be well-documented, and follow best practices Include comments in code cells to explain what each step does.

The Jupytext should use `# %% [markdown]` for markdown cells and `# %%` delimiters for the code cells.

If any NWB have units objects, you should know the following:
units.spike_times_index[i] provides the vector of spike times for the i^th unit. It is actually not an index. Do not use units.spike_times.

Do not render or display the nwb object directly in the notebook as the output could be very large.

Use concise scientific language.

Your notebook will be evaluated based on the following criteria:
1. How well did the notebook help you understand the purpose and content of the Dandiset?
2. After reviewing the notebook, do you feel confident in how to access the different types of data from this Dandiset?
3. Did the notebook help you understand the structure of the NWB file(s) and how to work with them?
4. Did the visualizations in the notebook generally help you understand key aspects of the data?
5. Did any of the visualizations make it harder to understand the data (e.g., due to poor formatting, unclear axes, or misleading displays)?
6. Do you feel more confident creating your own visualizations of the data after seeing the examples in the notebook?
7. How well did the visualizations show the structure or complexity of the data?
8. Were there any interpretations or conclusions in the notebook that felt unclear or not well supported by the data shown?
9. Did any of the plots or examples feel unnecessarily repetitive or redundant?
10. Did the notebook help you understand what kinds of questions or analyses you could do next with this Dandiset?
11. How clear and easy was the notebook to follow?
12. Did the notebook provide code you could easily reuse or adapt to explore the Dandiset yourself?
13. Did the notebook help you understand what kinds of questions or analyses you could do next with this Dandiset?
14. Overall, how helpful was this notebook for getting started with this Dandiset?

Your output should be in the format:

<notebook>
The text of the jupytext notebook should appear here.
</notebook>

No other text should be included in the response.

<notebook>
# %% [markdown]
# # Exploring Dandiset 001433: Breathing Rhythm and Place Dataset

# %% [markdown]
# > **Note**: This notebook was generated with AI assistance. Please verify all code and results independently.

# %% [markdown]
# ## Overview
# This notebook explores Dandiset 001433 ([link](https://dandiarchive.org/dandiset/001433/0.250507.2356)), which contains behavioral and electrophysiological recordings from freely-behaving mice. The dataset includes:
# - Local field potential (LFP) recordings from the olfactory bulb
# - Breathing (sniffing) measurements
# - No explicit stimuli or tasks
#
# We will demonstrate how to:
# 1. Access the data using the DANDI API
# 2. Load and examine the NWB file structure
# 3. Visualize LFP and breathing signals
# 4. Analyze basic breathing patterns

# %% [markdown]
# ## Required Packages

# %%
import pynwb
import h5py
import remfile
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from dandi.dandiapi import DandiAPIClient

# %% [markdown]
# ## Loading Data from DANDI

# %%
# Initialize DANDI API client
client = DandiAPIClient()
dandiset = client.get_dandiset("001433", "0.250507.2356")

# Get the URL for our example file
url = next(dandiset.get_assets_by_glob("sub-4122/sub-4122_ses-20250507T152927_ecephys.nwb")).download_url

# Set up remote file access
remote_file = remfile.File(url)
h5_file = h5py.File(remote_file)
io = pynwb.NWBHDF5IO(file=h5_file)
nwb = io.read()

# %% [markdown]
# ## Data Structure Overview
# The NWB file contains several key components:
# - LFP recordings from 16 channels
# - Raw sniffing signal
# - Processed breathing events (inhalation and exhalation times)

# %% [markdown]
# ## Examining LFP and Breathing Signals

# %%
# Extract LFP and sniffing data
lfp_data = nwb.acquisition['LFP'].data
sniff_data = nwb.acquisition['SniffSignal'].data

# Plot a short segment (first 5 seconds) of data
sampling_rate = 1000  # Hz
time_window = 5  # seconds
samples = sampling_rate * time_window

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(12, 8), sharex=True)

# Plot LFP from first channel
time = np.arange(samples) / sampling_rate
ax1.plot(time, lfp_data[:samples, 0], 'b-', label='Channel 0')
ax1.set_ylabel('LFP (V)')
ax1.set_title('LFP Recording')
ax1.legend()

# Plot sniffing signal
ax2.plot(time, sniff_data[:samples], 'k-')
ax2.set_xlabel('Time (s)')
ax2.set_ylabel('Sniff Signal (V)')
ax2.set_title('Breathing Signal')

plt.tight_layout()

# %% [markdown]
# ## Analyzing Breathing Events

# %%
# Get inhalation and exhalation times
inhale_times = nwb.processing['behavior'].data_interfaces['inhalation_time'].timestamps
exhale_times = nwb.processing['behavior'].data_interfaces['exhalation_time'].timestamps

# Calculate breathing intervals
breath_intervals = np.diff(inhale_times)

# Plot histogram of breathing intervals
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.hist(breath_intervals, bins=50, alpha=0.7)
plt.xlabel('Interval between inhalations (s)')
plt.ylabel('Count')
plt.title('Distribution of Breathing Intervals')
plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)

# %% [markdown]
# ## Accessing Electrode Information

# %%
# Convert electrodes table to a more readable format
electrodes_df = nwb.electrodes.to_dataframe()
print("Number of electrodes:", len(electrodes_df))
print("\nElectrode locations:")
print(electrodes_df['location'].unique())
print("\nFiltering applied:")
print(electrodes_df['filtering'].unique())

# %% [markdown]
# ## Next Steps
# This dataset enables various analyses:
# 1. Relationship between breathing patterns and LFP signals
# 2. Spatial organization of LFP activity across electrodes
# 3. Temporal structure of breathing rhythms
#
# The code provided here can be adapted to:
# - Analyze different time windows
# - Examine other electrode channels
# - Compute additional breathing metrics
# - Investigate relationships between LFP and breathing patterns
</notebook>
